results.title: beta-blocker prescription is associated with lower cumulative risk of knee osteoarthritis and knee pain consultations in primary care: a propensity score-matched cohort study
results.text_hl: Commonly used beta-blockers have analgesic properties for @DISEASE_Musculoskeletal_Pain @DISEASE_MESH:D059352 @@@musculoskeletal pain@@@. @<m>CHEMICAL_Atenolol</m> @CHEMICAL_MESH:D001262 @@@Atenolol@@@ might be a therapeutic option for @DISEASE_Osteoarthritis @DISEASE_MESH:D010003 @@@OA@@@ and @DISEASE_Cardiovascular_Diseases @DISEASE_MESH:D002318 @@@cardiovascular@@@ co@<m>DISEASE_614963</m> @DISEASE_OMIM:614963 @@@-morbidities@@@ in which beta-blockers are indicated, while @CHEMICAL_Propranolol @CHEMICAL_MESH:D011433 @@@propranolol@@@ may be suitable for people with co-morbid @DISEASE_Anxiety @DISEASE_MESH:D001007 @@@anxiety@@@.

citations.NLM: Nakafero G, Grainge MJ, Valdes AM, Townsend N, D Mallen C, Zhang W, Doherty M, Mamas M, Abhishek A. beta-blocker prescription is associated with lower cumulative risk of knee osteoarthritis and knee pain consultations in primary care: a propensity score-matched cohort study Rheumatology (Oxford). 2021 Dec 1;60(12):5686-5696. PMID: 33710319
